Mr David Cameron said: I am very sorry that Andy Coulson has decided to resign as my director of communications, although I understand that the continuing pressures on him and his family mean that he feels compelled to do so.`` Andy Coulson has told me that the focus on him was impeding his ability to do his job and was starting to prove a distraction for the government. The statement comes just days after the prime minister refused to deny reports that Mr Andy Coulson had already offered his resignation. he had to resign. But the precedent is a bad one. As I wrote last September, when Keith Vaz , the Labour chairman of Commons home affairs select committee, was upping the ante, Andy Coulson 's antagonists seem to be forging a new and frankly preposterous politico-legal doctrine of executive responsibility: namely, that a man should not only lose the job he holds at the time of the wrongdoing, but all subsequent jobs. On this sinister basis, one strike and you are out- forever. Andy Coulson has now lost two very senior positions in less than four years without a single allegation against him having been proved. Politics- and government- will be poorer without him. But more honourable and
